text: Hazy amber pour with aroma of caramel, bread, and dark fruit. Caramel and fruit sweetness with some grain and touch of tartness. Nice beer.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2015 On cask at the brewpub, this was better than expected. Slight haze on a pale yellow beer. Wine like aroma. Decent mild flavors. Has a slight hint of tartness in the background. Yes, turning out to be a pretty good example of esb. One of the better esbs I think Ive had in a while. Surprizingly good co2 effect, even on cask!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Heck yeah. Nice ESB. Biscuity, malty, good head retention. Little on the hoppier side of the ESB equation. Got some sweetness to it I wasn't expecting. Great beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask. Dark yellow faint sweet nose. Barely any malt backbone, thin and faint sugary sweet. Dank finish

Poured into English pint a cloudy copper. Head was tan, fine bubbled and lasting. Fine lacing on glass. Aroma was hoppy with grapefruit notes. Tast was citrus with the grapefruit getting stronger towards finish as the bitterness. Also gets a little more malty in the late finish. Bottle conditioned there was some sediment. I will add to the former complaints to why the year is not on the bottle. I didnt know when buying if it was good for 6 months or expired for 6 months. (Mine was fresh) Enjoyed.

Draft at Devil's Advocate. Pours a yellowish amber color with a thin white head an a little lacing. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, orange, grapefruit. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is bitter, hoppy, pine, some nutty sweetness, with a dry, bitter finish.

Cask at brewpub. Now this is more like it. Pours brown with a thin white head. Nice grapefruit on the nose. I definitely get citrus on the tongue. Finishes with a touch of bitterness. I find most bitters boring but this one kicks ass!

22 oz. bottle for $3.99 @ Garys Beverage. This was marked down and I could tell has been sitting awhile after knocking off 3 inches of dust off the bottle. Aroma is floral hops with a touch of citrus. Flavor is surprisingly bitter with lots of floral hops and some bland malt. A wet hop type bitterness. I really, REALLY wanted to like this brew but I just didnt.

bomber: Copper pour with a thin head.
aroma was floral, fruity and caramel maltiness. 
flavour is caramel maltiness, more herbal and woody than floral hop. 
Very light in body. 
Will have to try again, but was a bit underwhelmed on this occassion.

(bottle) Regarding the bottle expiration, I have the same complaint as the last rater, whats the year of expiration?  Mine tasted old.  Hazy orange complexion with thick long-lasting tan head. The flavor is untraditionally hoppy with citrus undertones. Full bodied and nice mouth feel. A unique bend on this style.

From a bomber, said best before Nov.  But what year?  Bought in Mar. 2012.  Bottle opened releasing great pressure, but foamed like crazy when poured into clean glass.  I ended up with 1" of beer and 6" of foam.  I suspect this bottle was well past, which is a shame as I was looking forward to tasting a top rated Bitter, as I like the style.  Very bitter in the nose and extremely bitter in the finish.  Carbonation was very lively in the mouth as well.  Tasted like an over the top hopped IPA.  Head retention and lacing was the most I have ever seen.  Maybe my opinion will improve if I ever get to taste a fresh one.

Bomber pours amber with a ridiculous brown head made it very difficult to pour. Aromas of fruit rind and grapefruit. Flavor is bitter with a bit of pine. Body is medium light and finish is abrupt.  Also not sure why its rated so high

bottle aquired in trade with shcufj on BA, best before Feb 2012.

Hazy copper hut with strong 1" head with beyond excellent retention. bread light flower, and yeast in the nose. Taste is well balanced, just basic malt and flower hop. mouth is light to medium bodied with plenty of carbonation to help.

Bomber from Carl K. Pours bright copper with a 3 finger frothy beige head. Aroma is floral and lightly malty with a touch of citrus. Med body. Flavor is light roast caramel with something like grapefruit rind. I have no idea where the floral went. The finish is nice bitter somewhat conquering tasty caramel. I still think theres floral in the aroma. Nice ale.
Cloudy copper color with large white foamy head.  Piney aroma.  Malty flavor followed by tartness and piney finish.
I cannot see why this is highly regarded.  Very boring even for a bitter.  It is bitter but the hops dont add much.  Tastes like a highly bitter irish red.

Poured from a 650ml into a tulip glass.

A: Hazy brown with a lot of carbonation bubbles and a white foamy head. Looked a lot like carbonated iced tea.

S: Fruity hoppy with a mix of malts thrown in there.

T: A bit bland, malty upfront into a very watery mid with a light hoppy finish. 

M: Too watery and too much carbonation.

O: An okay beer. I wouldnt buy it again because it didnt stand out at all.
This needs some time to open up or it really sucks. Ahhhhhhhhh. Malty aroma not much bitterness. Def a nightcap.
Draught, 5.5%. Weak refreshing hop aroma. Cloudy grey golden colour. Slightly sweet. Good rough hop flavour. Slightly rough finish.

Cloudy light copper coloured body with a thin white head that leaves a nice lace. Aroma of light earthy (english) hops, strong malt, a touch of alcohol and a bunch of bright floral notes. Light to Medium-bodied; Strong assertive floral flavour with a bit of light malt, some light alcohol and a large dose of english hops. Aftertaste shows pretty much only light hops, floral notes and a light touch of malt. Overall, nice, but a bit lacking in complexity and strong flavours. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Liqour Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 08-May-2011 sampled at home in Washington on 04-September-2011.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a fair amount of head.  Bitter malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bomber.  Pours dark amber with a big, dense off-white head and gobs of sentiment at the bottom of the bottle.  Aroma is mildly bready, some citrus hops.  Flavor is surprisingly bitter with lots of caramel, bready malt, and some fruit that emerges as it warms.  Wish I would have waited til it warmed more, because it really came on in the end.  A solid bitter.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 8/5/11


Aroma: The nose has some grassy and floral hops, and some caramel too

Appearance: It pours a mostly clear dark orange-brown color with a creamy beige head

Flavor: Tastes fairly bitter, lightly sweet, similar to the nose, plus some sour notes as well

Palate: The body is medium, with a somewhat sticky mouthfeel, and a tingly/lively carbonation

Overall Impression: 
Overall, I wanted to like this one more then I actually did.  The taste just had something off about it, like an unintended sourness.  I dont know if it was a bad bottle, or just not a great beer, but it wound up disappointing me just a little.
On tap at Brewery. Murky golden body with top head. Nose is malts and some caramel. Taste is hops and bitter, really bitter. Quite enjoyable. Especially at the quaint and rowdy brewpub.

Nice strong off-white head of fine bubbles.  Reduces slowly and leaves a thick sheet of lacing.  Weak aroma with some light malts and some mild cheese.  Color is a hazy medium brown.  Toasted grains, some caramel malts, a bit of dry chalkyness and some tea leaves.  Mild bitterness but backed with a bit of slick malts.  Kind of a slight sourness to this brew also.  Finishes rather bitter with some lingering dry malts.  This is a bit of a confusing brew but a decent one.
22 oz bottle.  Pours Copper amber in color with a pure white fluffy head.  The aroma is tangy, and grassy hops.  There is a fruity malt note, adding just enough balance to the beer.  Very dry finish.

As with most bitters, lack of an aroma lowers the score but this is one fine bitter. The aroma is bread and yeast and a bit of malt. The flavor is malty sweet up front and then just bitingly bitter. It is extremely dry and refreshing.

Orange with a white head.  Citrus and lemon in the aroma with light sweetness.  Flavor is very citrus and earthy with a nice biscuit malt profile.  More bitter than I expected.  Pretty solid and would be nice on a warm summer night.

Amber hazy body with a huge yellow off white head.  Malty and hoppy aroma.  Hints of caramel malt, pine and floral notes with a duller bitter pb note (this fades as I continue through the ale).  Bitter hop character with a thin spruce and herbal hop character.  Nice clean hoppy bitter ale, and one of the better core beers ive had from Mcneils.

Sampled at Nashville Beer Summit 1.22.11 - Pours a light copper brown. Lighter weight beer for such strong hoppy good bitterness. Nice long finish. The mid palate is lacking a touch. But part of that is the other crazy huge beers Ive been sampling today. Darn good ESB. One of the best.
22oz - Malty nose, frothy head, solid palate, some hoppy bitterness.  Delivered as advertised, nicely so.
Gold pour with white head and lace. Light grapefruit aroma. Sweet caramel malt with medium/light citrus bitter. Medium bodied and fizzy. Good beer.

22 oz bottle shared at Dereks Tasting. Pours a hazy amber, murky really, with a big frothy offwhite head that stays big. Aromas are decent florals, touches of lemon, bitter florals, with touch of pine, bread and biscuits. Initial is medium bready, biscuits, toffee, florals, pine, touch of soap and lemon rind peek in. Finish is lightly dry, bitter, light sweetness. A nice lighter balanced ESB without a big hop presence overall. Not bad, perhaps a bit older with a touch of oxidation, apparent fade.

Bottle. Pours orange with a light beigeish head. Citric hoppy aroma with some light crackery malts. Crisp hoppy flavor with floral and citric notes on a pale malty base. Hoppy for its style but still good.

Bottle shared by Sean, thanks! Poured a clear hazy amber with a brown hue and a gray head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma had a nice citrus presence with some hay, sweet grain and grass as well. Flavor started citrus and grass which mellowed into a malt finish consisting of grain and bread.

Pour is deep cloudy amber with nice head and strong sticky lacing.  Flavor is bitter with strong hops and sticky and mildly sweet maltiness in the finish.  This beer starts bitter and has a nice citrus finish.  Overall a bit sticky and the flavor stays with you but not in a way that is obtrusive.  This is a really nice beer.

Amber. Fast, off-white head. Aroma: Cascade Hops with malt bready backing. Flavor: English Hops, Citris. Dry finish.  One of the best Bitters I have had.  This, with Rogue Brutal Bitter shows that America can match the Motherland on ESBs (and IPAs).

Bottle thanks to mymrnngjckt on BA.  Dirty light brown pour, a little carbonation and a slightly sweet floral aroma.  Flavor is medicinal Ricola cough drops, bitter cereal malts and finished very dry and bitter on the aftertaste.  Interesting beer, but not something Id go searching for.
Coppery color with a foamy whitish tan head. A nice balanced flavor with a nice bitter hoppy finish. Citrus and grassiness in the taste as well. A bit hoppier than some ESBs, but nice.
brings a great feeling of balance of malty, the palate is thinner than desirable but the malts are rich and sweet and the hops bring a nice piny sharpness to it.

The aroma is a good balance of grassy hops and sweet malt but it also has a bit of grain husks and leaves. The appearance is milky amber with a medium foamy head that fades a little too quick. The taste is like the aroma with a bitter finish. The palate is thin but smooth. Overall not a bad beer but too bitter for the style.

22oz bottle. Poured a deeper amberish color with a averaged sized off white head. Cloudy. Aromas of floral hops, some citrus, caramel, and bready. Tastes of the same breadiness, toasted caramel, and lighter citrus.

Bomber. Hazy, darkish copper with a lasting disc of foam. Nose of caramel, banana, apple, and hints of orange and wood. Flavor is caramel, banana, bubble gum and an overarching bitter woodiness. Long bittersweet finish of peppery earth and wood has touches of citrus bubble gum. Light-medium body is smoothly carbonated and astringently dry.

22 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy orange brown color with a thin off white film.  The aroma has moderately sweet caramel/toffee, ripe fruits and floral hops.  The flavor opens with moderate sweetness favoring caramel malt and ripe fruits, but becomes increasingly biscuity and toasted midway through the finish.  Still some fruitiness perhaps grapefruit, bitterness at the back and finishes dry.  Medium bodied; just ok.

Big ol Bomber bottle! Crisp, almost red pour with a nice head. Bitter is right! Very tasty. Citrus, barley a little wheat and a nice balance.. Got to get more of this!
Enjoy

Aroma is some prickly pale malts, with a hint of caramel. A mild, woody hop. Touch of yeast.

The appearance is medium orange with a cloudy half-finger of head.

The flavor is sweet malts, just short of a brown ale, but with a flowery hop that finishes like pine oil. Sweet and then just a tad astringent, a bit metallic.

Feels smooth and oily. Decent body. A tad prickly. Really easy drinkin. More of an English ESB than anything. Pleasant and not too challenging.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 Pours a slightly hazy, almost copper body with a lacing, off-white head.  Aromas of caramel, malt, some hops.  Flavors of caramel, earthy/grass hops, and toasty nuttiness, almost cocoa.  Slightly dry finish.  Bitter.  Nice, medium-bodied brew.

5/18/2010:  McNeills Extra Special Bitter Ale...  Aroma:  Floral hops; hint of cooked caramel and apple.  Appearance:  Muddy, dull amber color; moderate carbonation; minimal flat beige head.  Flavor:  Perfume and sugary grapefruit hop flavor and bitterness accompanied by a toffee maltiness.  Palate:  Medium-bodied; average mouthfeel.  Overall:  Decent overall; a bit heavy hopped and thick for an ESB; more like an IPA...
1 pint 6 fl. oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #108 for this beer.

Bottle. Poured hazy brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt and bitter aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.
Dark brown-amber, nice beige cover.  Aroma is caramel, toffee, nice citrusy, spicy aroma.  Taste is more candies, toffee, herbal bitter finish.
Beer exploded on me upon opening. Pours golden copper with lots of head. Aroma is citrus spruce. Taste is pleasant bitter hop. Rated 2/21/05

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2011 Bottle curteousy of Pwn3d. Pour is a dark orange/brown. Aroma is light with notes of sweet bitter hops. Taste is bitter hop and a brilliant malty sweetness. Palate is medium, nice long bitter finish. RERATE:: Draft at RnH with Linh. Pours an amber orange body with light haze. Aroma is bitter hops. Mouthfeel is dry with bitter hops colliding with a sweet malty profile underneath. Okay ESB.

Bottle shared with JRedmond.  Pour is a dark brown.  Taste is very bitter hop coupled with a nice sweetness from the malts.  One of the longer finishes Ive tasted.. Bitter, sharp,  and delicious.  This is a nice medium between aggressive and sessionable.

chill this until it is not too cold and then pour some into a glass. taste it and then let it sit for a few minutes and then taste it again. ooohhh boy that is good. hops, sweet candy grapefruit, a good malt profile and a refreshing and zingy carbonation....this is a real winner. mid palate of hops, malt and poison ivy it ends with sweet grapefruit pith that is sweet like candy. just in that order.

light golden pour, frothy white head.  Aroma is slightly earthy spice, some light hopping, a bit of a Rubbery aroma,  some nice floral notes. Lightly creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is nutty, sweet caramel and toffee, grassy malt and spicey hopping.  Pretty tasty
Draft @ Coles, Buffalo, NY. Copper colored pour. Medium rich malt aroma, mild english hops. Taste was well balanced, malty richness, tempered with right amount of hop bitterness. Solid ESB

22 oz. bomber.  Very nice pour, a somewhat maroon color, with frothy off white head.  Sweet malty nose, butter, toffee, also floral hop scent.  Taste sort of balanced but kind of hop dominated, piny, with malt backbone and pleasant hop bitterness on finish.  This would really be a great session beer, and would go great with food, though it seems more like a pale ale than ESB.

From the 1 pint 6. fl. oz. bottle. Best before the last day of April (10, I assume). The pour is a nice looking amber color with excellent clarity considering it is marketed as unfiltered.  About three-quarters of an inch of frothy cream colored head and clinging lacing on the glass.  An aromatic floral hoppy feel to its scent. Its bitternesss is enhanced by its hoppy quality.  A nice beer.

22oz bottle.... pours a slightly hazy apple cider brown with a fluffy white head....aroma of grassy hops and pale malt, somewhat grainy.....slightly bitter and grassy hops, more hop dominated with an almost unnoticeable malt presence.  finishes on a bitternote.  refreshing at first but bitterness becomes a little overbearing.  just havent been able to enjoy this style as much as others.
on cask-pours an off white head that bubbles and gold color.  Aroma is mild sweet light malt.  Taste is mild sweet light malt, secondary herbal hops.  Close to a bitter.

Bottle.  Pours a clear orange with a HUGE foamy white head.  Aroma of sweet light malts, floral hops.  Flavor is sweet and puckering up front with a fruity (like fruit punch) finish.  Slightly astringent with malty cereal graininess.  Im not really a fan of the McNeills house flavor, which seems to be present in all their beers.  This isnt too bad, but it isnt too good either.
6/4/6/3/13 (3.2/5)

Tap at Blind Tiger. Aroma of huge, toasted caramel malt, bread crust, spicy hop character, peppery, zesty, a trickle of fresh-squeezed orange juice. Flavor opens up very bitter for an ESB and exhibits a juicy hop character with a straight bitter finish. As it warms, the sweet malt catches up and actually overtakes the bitter aspects by the end, even going a bit too sweet for me beyond the lovely toastedness I felt in the aroma. Fairly full-bodied, maybe a bit too much residual sugar in there. Still, not shabby at all.
Slightly cloudy dark copper color with a head you could rest a playing card on.  Nice lightly metallic hop aroma, hints of leather and fruit.  Firm hop bitterness in the flavor that lasts well after.

Thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Grapefruit orange, large proud head. Floaties too. Aroma: Grapefruit, hops, lemons, very sweet. Flavour: Grapefruit, hops, almost IPA like, lots of carbonation, very bitter too.Very nice

Bottle (22oz).  Shared with blankboy and garthicus, via trade with glouglouburp.  Incredibly cloudy deep orange pour, lots of floaties, and a huge fluffy beige head.  Dry, pungently floral/herbal aroma, peppery and spicy, a slightly lemony sourness to it.  The taste followed the nose, slightly pungent and sour, a touch papery in the malt body, but plenty of herbal bitterness.  Dry, sharply carbonated mouthfeel, with a long astringent/bitter finish --- maybe a tad too dry, but a very long-lasting bitter ale, definitely NOT filtered.

Bottle (22oz) shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a deep cloudy orange-amber with a trillion stationary floaties and a large lasting frothy off-white head -- cool! Nice aroma, lots of hops -- floral, spicy and piney -- backed by caramel malt, fruit and light spices. Refreshing and tasty flavour is hoppy, nicely backed by caramel malt along with some spices and some fruit and has a nice bitter finish. Medium bodied. Man, I really liked this!

In short: A yeasty messy hoppy beer.  Surprisingly interesting mess.
How:  Bottle 22oz, drank the day of purchase (therefore most likely very fresh)
The look: Cloudy orange body topped by a medium off-white head
In long: Nose is floral and citrus.  Mouthfeel is like a pillow.  Definitely very yeasty, a lot more than a normal ESB.  This is a fluffy beer with citrus, wood juice, dry tree leaves, a little farmhouse thing, a few dried apricots, and some other stuff.  The beer is actually quite messy and unfocussed.  Feels like a amateurish lucky shot.  The antithesis of the clean crisp beer.  Whatever, when very fresh this is a surprisingly good mess.  Props to McNeils to be capable to make a mess so enjoyable, when I make one of my own I need a mop and a whole lot of air freshener aerosol.

(Bottle).  Aroma of hops and slight citrus.  Pours hazy orange with a thick creamy head.   Flavor difficult to pin down.  Bitter with some sourness and citrus, and a very long pleasant finish.  Overall, very different from Fuller’s ESB, with more of a bitter bite.
(22oz bottle)  Pours an amber body with a small bubbly white head.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, and citrus.  Flavor of caramel and hops (citrus, herbal).
red-gold. hoppy aroma. likewise, it tasted hoppy.  slight spice in a medium body with a soft feel.  didnt stand out or seem like anything special to me, however.

Cask at McNeills.  hazy amber beer, creamy tan head.  Fresh hoppy aroma.  Spicy and fairly woody.  Nice fresh bready back note with a light mineral quality.  Soft texture, with an excellent balance of woody UK-type hops and toasty pale malt.  Lightly resiny.

Pours a hazy copper, amber color with only a moderate head and some lacing. While pouring it, it seemed a little flat. Tasted fine though. Hoppy, sweet aroma. Pretty nice. Tasted quite hoppy (although not too much), sweet with sugary notes that made it seem maybe a little sweet. Slightly bitter and spicy as well. Good overall tasting beer but a touch too sweet for me. Hops do dominate the flavor so be sure you like hoppy beers when you drink this one.
This beer is extremely drinkable and so would make a great pub beer. A little more hoppy than the avg. bitter but it works well.

Pours a nice peachy golden with some head.  Significant English hop aroma.It was a nice bitter, with a bit of a background edge.  FIne drinking but not the best bitter I have tried.
Picked it up in August, but did not notice it expired in September, but I do not think that would make a significant impact.
McNeills ESB is one of my favorite beers. The method of dry-hopping adds a pleasant floral aroma to an alreadfy seriously-hopped, well balanced English ale. Near perfect!
Sampled at brewery Pours a medium brown with a off white head. Aroma is caramel malt,citrus hop and some fruit. Flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter from the hops. medium to full bodied. A decent esb

Pleasant, earthy and bitter aroma.  Very inviting.  The flavor is similar, and even more bitter than I expected from the somewhat malty-sweet aroma.  The flavor does not have much sweetness at all, and is predominately bitter hops.

So I bought this knowing it was past its prime, because the last Mcneills brew I had past its prime was pretty freakin good (God bless the funk!) - the cap less popped off than it did tear off, leaving some interesting crud around the lip of the bottle (oh yea!) - cloudy orange pour, with small ring of lace - aroma of biscuity british malt, highly floral hops, apricot, and some slight musty, earthy, almost barnyardy qualities (theres some of that funk starting to form in this one) - citrusy palate up front, but a lot of the malt flavor seems to have become stale, making room for some oxidation and a tiny bit of sourness that combines well with the hop bitterness and herbal flavors - apricots and peaches arrive late - lingering hops - fresh this is probably awesome, and with a little more time in the bottle to let those micro-organisms work their magic will probably make it awesome in a different way - for now its just pretty good.

Bottle via Thaichile, thanks for another great one, Mark!   Pours a cloudy, rusty, amber color with a substantial beige colored head.   Aroma is grassy, cramel malt, floral hops, bread.   Flavor is apricot, caramel, citrus, bread.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, nice spicy, floral-like finish.   Good stuff here.

Good looking ESB. Nice bit of hops on the nose, but not overwhelmingly so. Grapefruit up front, which balances out evenly.  Got this one cask conditioned from McNeills, I feel like this is probably the only way to have it.
Bottle (rating from August 2005 notes).  A cloudy apricot color with a laced white head.  Smooth with well rounded and robust flavors.  Peach and floral notes.  A very nice ESB.

An elite ESB, and perhaps the best Ive yet quaffed.  The pour is turbid medium copper with medium off-white head.  Aroma is big hops, fruit, some caramel malt.  Rather dense palate with tons of complexity and balance, and a huge hop flavor matched by solid caramel malt and subtle fruit.  I tasted something different with every sip of this one.  Awesome!
This is a great ESB!  Go to the brewery and get it on cask to thoroughly enjoy the flavors.  Very tasty beer!

Drinking this one of the bank of Charles river in Boston, hazy amber color, with a frothy beige head. The nose is one of a nice floral hop, with a grassiness note, hint a crystal malt and citrus fruits in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with floral hop character, with some grassy, leafy, piney notes, hint of sweet caramelized malt, and hint of grapefruit fruitiness leading towards a flowery bitter finish.

En cask chez McNeills. Robe blonde aux reflets cuivrés voilée et surmontée dune mousse blanche crémeuse qui persiste. Arômes légers de houblon. Saveurs de carton, de houblon amérisant, de liège et dagrumes.

been drinking this for years and know it well.  bottle and tap, unquestionably the best ale I have ever had.  consider yourself lucky if you have regular access to this ale.  been road tripping about 250 miles 1 way to buy quantities and visit the pub a few times/year.  there is something special going on at mcniells.  visit the pub, put it on the top of your to do list.

Ruby amber ale with a big bubbled off white head. Classy british hops and caramel malt aroma. Restrained malts and lightlly pungeant hops in mouth, with good citrus notes. Very classy. On tap Feb. 10, 2006.

On cask at the pub....
Aroma:light hopy nose...
Appearance:Clear amber big head...
Flavor:Good bitterness,light caramel flavor.....
Pours deep copper/amber into a pint.  Well-formed head with nice lacing.  Very well balanced -- caramel and bitter hop finish.

Bomber.  Poured a clear medium caramel with a tall, rocky white head... left some nice lacing and there was some light sediment suspended in there (much, much more from the bottom on the second pour).  Sweet pine tar in the nose... lots of citrus hoppage (grapefruit and lemon zest), but there was a significant amount of sweet maltage that provided a nice balance.  Flavor followed the aroma quite well... lots of pine and citrus hoppage, with a medium caramel backbone.  Dont think this was the freshest sample, though... as the flavors werent as crisp as expected or described below.

Out of a bomber.  Aroma heavily hopped very piney. Pour was a hazed orange to amber.   Flavor was good the hops had a good enough bite yet a mellow sweetness.  Body was nice and finish was just bitter enough.  I liked this one alot.

Reddish amber, good foaming head. Strong herbal hop aroma, and a definite British influence with a fairly sweet malt profile and well developed light-fruit esters. Hop flavors are low, but a strong finishing bitterness sets this apart. Medium bodied.

Couleur ambrée tirant vers le rouge-brun.  Mousse blanche concassée, mi-abondante, adhérant bien à la paroi du verre.  Plein de houblons floraux, une trace de diacetyl, malt grillé suggérant le pain grillé, le café et les noisettes.  Finale amérisante et pas tout à fait propre soulevant quelques questions qui demeurent pour linstant sans réponse.  En fût chez McNeills le 22 Mai 2005.
[Cask at GBBF 2004] An amber beer with no head. The aroma is very grassy and the so is the flavor - it tastes like eating fresh hops - too much for me. The hops dries out the mouth.
Murky rust; wispy head. Nose very similar to an English ESB. Murky hop flavor? A little to dry for my tastes. Alcohol is evident.
Bottle. Cloudy orange and yellow in color with a nice white head. Hop aroma. Citrus hops. Citrus hop flavor. Very hoppy Esb.  No malt character whatsoever. Nice beer.

Bottle. Cloudy orange yellow, white head. Citrussy hop aroma. Massive citrus hop flavor. Chinook? This is an over the top hopped ESB, if there is such a thing. Very Grapefruity. No real malt character. All citrus. Kinda fun.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Let me preface this review by saying that I was really looking forward to trying some of the beers from this brewpub on draught, but to my disappointment, arrived a few hours before they open.  Unable to wait around, I was forced to leave disappointed.  That disappointment quickly changed when I found a few bottles of this beer at a store in MA.  Pours a healthy orange with a small lingering head.  Nice and malty in taste with a hint of orange and possibly banana.  A very good brew.  Ill make sure I can stop in and try them out again when they are open the next time Im in VT.

Cloudy Orange gold. No head. sweetly spicy aroma. Very citrusy, resiny hop flavor, loong aftertase. It has very "fresh" taste - all the flavors "pop" as you drink it. Notes of resin in the finish. Tasty.

pours a nice cloudy orange brown. no head. malty raisin and plum aroma. dry sweet flavor with a nice bitterness at the end that is similar to a barleywine that is interesting, this also had an interesting sharp cheddar flavor
Amber with thin tan head...smelled malty and a hint of pepper?...taste was quite generic...malty and thin with mild hoppy finish...not bad...
Bottle. My first thought on my first sip was, "Who put Alka-Seltzer in my beer?". A lot of stinging CO2. Strong cereal and malt flavors. Kind of an astringent bitter.

This ESB pours with a crystal clear, amber body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet, grapefruity and hoppy with a slight pine note and a touch of malt.  A great aroma.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter from the hops wtih a slight grapefruit note, some piney notes and a very bitter finish.  Medium to full bodied, slightly dry and smooth.

2004 bottle.  Color:  Bottle conditionied.  Light reddish-brown.  Light golds and yellows mixed in with a creamy, off-white mocha colored head.  Aroma of extra-fruity hops, tons of ripe red and yellow fruits; very fragrant.  Flavor:  Begins quite dry and bitter, with some light fruit making itself known (strawberries, tart cherries).  The hops seem very strong and bitter however, though its an ESB, I prefer a more traditional, more malty/earthy rendition.  The flavor was certainly there, just too in your face bitter for my likes.  Palate showed a creamy, lightly bubbly, medium bodied ale.  Dry on the finish, peppery almost with hints of grapefruit.

Bottle 8/26/04:  Poured a light amber/orange color with a small white head.  Aroma of floral hops, grapefruit, herbs, bitter malt, and earth tones.  Tastes like bitter, floral hops to start, moves to a sweeter hops and dark, bitter malt taste with some grapefruit, then finishes moderately dry, bitter, with hints of earth and chocolate on the tongue.  Medium body, lively carbonation.  Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2009 Cask, poured a copper color with a creamy off white head and nice lacing on the glass.  Fruity and freshly herbal hop aroma.  Lightly bitter hops and a pleasant fruity citrus taste.  Soft and creamy mouthfeel.   2/09 - New bottles purchased in Massachusetts are fantastic!
GBBF, London, gravity I think. Mid-brown, no head. The first beer of the fest, and a good one too. Crisp, full and very tasty. Extremely dry hoppy on the finish, with a crunchy, refreshing quality.

Cask conditioned - gravity- GBBF 2004.  A very English type beer brewed in USA.  The aroma and taste are mostly bitter whilst the colour is mid brown.  I didnt get that American hoppiness at all.  Ok but uninspiring.

Bottle - Pours a very dark amber with that thin white head and lottle carbonation.  Aroma is of citrus hops and little else. A little thin.   Flavor is strongly of citrus/grapefruit hops and little else.  Nicely bitter.  Finish is citrus sourwith a good amount of hop bitterness and some residual malt sweetness.  This is a hopheads dream beer...

Spicy, fruity hop aroma, complimented by juicy, full, sweet malts.  Some caramel and mild toastiness is offset by the citric and mildly earthy hops, with grapefruit, tea leaves and pine lurking in the background.  Medium copper color, massive amounts of sediment chunking up the brew but good.  Flavor is primarily hoppy as well, again fruity and citric, quite bitter, but with a good dosage of malt on the back end to bring a bit of sweetness and some semblance of overall balance.  Medium bodied, mouthfeel is a little bit watery with some very fine but active carbonation.  Aggressively hopped.  Refreshing and highly drinkable.  Thanks, Mike!
Hazy amber in color with a small white head. Flora and earthy  hop aroma with mild malt. Flavor is hoppy,with a mild acidity and caramel tone. Finishes bitter and hoppy.

Perhaps my favorite american ESB.  Nice undertones that remind me of a real ale from the UK -- and not a Boddingtons.  Excellent off the tap as well as in their 22 oz bottle.  Great feeling in your mouth.  Recommended!

22oz bomber...slightly hazy dark amber pour with no head, that kinda worries me.  Somewhat malty nose mixed with slight aroma of hops.  Start is slightly sweet, quickly turning to an intense bitter that intensifies through the middle and then falls off to finish.  Nice dry finish, good amount of bitter, a solid brew.

Medium sized tan head, Tight beaded with a nice stringy, lasting lace. Hazy amber/copper color. Fruity, citrusy nose with some buttery notes also.Medium body lightly oily. Hoppy, resiny flavors with an excellent malt backbone, well balanced, too the hoppy side of course, YEA! Finish is dry, fruity with a gutsy hop bite. Highly quaffable. Thanks Oldgrowth!
Aroma of powerfull hops with some caramel. The flavor of great hops bitterness is followed by a nice, sweet, malty, caramel flavor. A very rich, complex ESB.

Light bronze body, bottle-conditioned with tons of sediments. Light beige head, big and medium lasting. Very citrusy aroma: grapefruit, orange, peach, lemon) but also a great malt counterpart of molasses and toffee by masses.. Palate is also very citrusy with a very direct bitter bite, quite citric/tart like a mild grapefruit juice, lemony. Not quite up to the superb aroma in my opinion. Medium bodied with just the right carbonation. Quite an extreme rendition of the style which you can't help, but appreciate.

What a pour! Perfect clear sparkling copper body with lively bubbles rising to the top to form a very nice rocky light tan head that forms big sheets of lacing. Looks awesome! The aroma is beautiful citrus, grapefruit, slight cinnamon, sweet malt. Yum. Finally the first sip, sweet caramel up front then develops into a good bit of citrus hops that provide a medium amount of bitterness. Towards the end of the swallow a good bit of raosted malt nutty flavor kicks in. The body is medium-full and almost creamy. The finish is dominated by the nutty roasted malt flavors with some bitterness lingering. This is the only flaw in an otherwise masterful beer.
GABF '03. Tasting notes didn't have anything good to say, so I will censor them for this site. &^$*@#(!@^*)%& . How's that?

Wow! A true English style bitter without all the Americanized hop presence. Malt is perfect, providing sustantial body.  The hop/malt interplay becomes lemony. Yeasty as hell (sedimentary), but rather neutral in taste. Up in the pantheon of three American takes on the English style (an exception is the more Americanized Schafly, IMO) - a triumvirate including Ballast Point's and Alesmith's.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Big juicy english hop aroma.  Light undertones of sweet malt.  Great malt smoothness.  Nice yeast profile.  Great bitter.
Cask-conditiioned version** Dark amber with frothy heaping head. Spicy aroma. Creamy mouthfeel with long sharply bitter finish. Excellent lacing.
Tap. Clear dark amber apperance. Mildly hoppy aroma. Clean hop flavors, both piney and citric. Not bad.

Lovely floral hop aroma.  Deep golden color with little head and lacing.  Light in body and very crisp.  Strong piney flavor for a bitter.  A little dose of that McNeil's aspirin-like flavor.  Very nice ale.
Dark amber with a gorgeous head and light lacing. Hoppy floral aroma. Flavor much the same, bitter and hoppy with tones of citrus and lightly malty. Not over the top bitter, fairly smooth.
[Cask conditioned] Deep amber coloured. Good balance between the hops and the malt. Bitter finish.
A cloudy autumn orange color, small white head.  An orange aroma, musty malts.  Some citrus notes in taste, decently bitter.  Average.

Hoppy, sweet aroma, golden amber color, although cloudy, and a dense creamy head that lasts forever. Flavors is hops up front, followed by malt, and a hoppy tail. Very definitely an American version, but a real nice ESB!

One hoppy ESB here! Nice amber color, and the head never went away. Some bread and grapefruit in the nose. Tiny amount of bready malt sweetness destroyed by a mountain of grapefruity hops in the mouth! Okay, I like my ESB with more of a malt backbone, but this stuff is dangerously drinkable.
Has a great clouded orange/amber color with some carbonation and a hop smell.  Taste is similar to the IPA, all hops.  Overall a good bitter beer.
Really liked this. Rich and citric, some caramelly malt. Bitter, citric finish, quite hoppy, i wish i could read the last word i wrote in my notes, but i can't, sorry (Cask -GBBF 03')
Gravity Cask, GBBF 2003  Citric aroma. Dark citric flavour. Fairly assertive. Not great.

(1 pint 6 ounce bottle) Pours a thin, white head and a red body with lots of sediment. Bitter hoppy nose. Its gorgeous... flowery and pink grapefruit. Huge hops, especially in the mid-palate and finish. Great stuff!

Identical to every other American beer I've had recently--big aroma!  Grapefruit and flower aroma.  Flavor shows some warmth and bitterness, with a bit of metal, slightly astringent.  A very hoppy ESB, a very American version of the English style, which may as well be called an IPA in this case.  Copper color with irregular head. (gravity pour at GBBF 2003)

Cask (gravity), GBBF2003. Amber colour moderate head and condition. Fruity hops in the nose, well balanced malt and hops in the mouth becoming very dry and hop bitter. The more I try of American Pale(ish) ales, the harder it is becoming to tell them apart.
Pours a copper brown with a thin whispy off-white head.  Huge complex malty and English hoppy aroma.  Body starts sweet and hoppy and turns more bitter toward the end.  This is a very good ESB.

Holy Head batman. I got a bottle of this from my local store, they had it shoved off into the back of the shelf and forgotten, I don't think it had the TLC beer needs.  It tasted oddly as well, it seemed too hoppy to be an ESB and reminded me more of a pale ale. That head though, I poured it, watied ten minutes and it was still there, I finally just ate it.
Dark copper brew with a wispy white head. Huge citrus nose. ESB? Medium light body that is only slightly balanced. This is not an ESB in my opinion. Very much a West Coast Pale/IPA.

Split this with herbjones at a mini southern california get together.
This was a dissappointing brew. It's not an ESB. It's more like a west coast IPA. Hoppy, Hoppy, Hoppy. No Malts at all. 
It's hazy golden golored with a huge hop aroma. I'd rate it higher if it were supposed to be an IPA

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2003 Okay I'm not rating an ESB here there must be a labeling problem.  As an ESB this beer is all wrong, not nearly malty enough and bittered with the wrong hops. The color is amber and transluscent again lighter than I'd expect for an ESB.  Ah, but I'm an IPA man and this is a pretty good one!  So I'm going to rate it as an IPA.  Pine and citrus bitterness apparent and dominant in both the flavor and taste.  It has enough sweetness to balance the hops, as any good IPA should.  Citrus dry finish this is a pretty good IPA, but really isn't much of an ESB.

From cask, warm. Frothy foamy head. Light brown color. Good amount of hops, yeah I agree a bit like an IPA with citrus/pine aroma and flavor, a little sweet and fruity overall.  Very easy to drink with almost no aftertaste.

Extremely hoppy for the style.  Reminds me of Rogue's Brutal Bitter.  Looked, smelled, and tasted like an IPA.  Pours a deep amber bronze with minimal head and a small amount of floaters in suspension.  Aroma is almost all hops, with a bit of estery fruitiness.  Taste is mostly hops, front to back, with a light malty background.  Not was i was expecting.  A really nice IPA, but not what I'm looking for in an ESB.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2003 From the bottle, 
Hoppy for a ESB. Bready piney aroma. Nice copper color. Head was low, but it was poured to leave sediment in bottle so the head stayed minimal. Grapefruity hops with a carmel malt taste. Leaves a bite on the tongue. Another winner from Ray.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 From the bottle:As the wealthy pine and orange curtain opens, Malteo and Hopiette, interpreted by multi-talented sapid actors, exchange lovely, entranced and flavorful words which cast awe and utopian visions into the bemused audience...The peachy footlights highlight Malteos complex poetry just as the dramatic forest setting breathes its endemic beauty onto Hopiettes tone...Backstage, Father Berry peers through, inquisitive and sagacious...The ending of this modern revision is much hoppier than the original and the crowd roars its approval...A loud and balanced curtain call follows the fabulous final love scene and the performance is celebrated until the wee hours of the night...4.3/5

On cask at the brewpub:A floral, citrusy bouquet imparts a more quaffable nature than the bottles and the hoppiness becomes less agressive and thus its bitterness is quietened. A tad less malty also than the bottle makes for an easier pint to quench yourself on. I still prefer the bottled version, but only by a body. Fresh grain and caramel appear, and the finish is quite bitter nonetheless (leafy, wooden). As eclectic as Brattleboro citizens. 3.8-4/5

worn copper like a sixty year old penny, the thick disc of creamy foam was given to exuberant expressions of elaborate lace.  nose of christmas hard candies, waffles and apples slathered with pineapple marmelade and spruce pitch.  on the upper slope of the tongue, the sweet elements: fruity caramels reinforced by a crack battalion of yeast-- make a brave, desparate stand, banners flying,  as wailing hordes of hops swirl round and round, pushing toward the back of the tongue, tightening the noose, and finally extinguishing the malts in a very long bitter finish.  smooth carbonation lets the struggle play out without interfereing. high drama in a glass, potent, with adult situations; not suitable for pre-teens.  (no ingredients were harmed in the making of this production).  two thumbs up.

Floral rounded sweet nose.  Huge rocky off-white head.  Tons of lace.  Garnett brown hue.  Lovely sweet start; medium bodied, awesome super-hopped bitter finish.  This is one hell of a sweet brew.  McNeills is one of the best brewerys in the northeast.

A lightly cloudy deep amber or copper if you prefer, the head is enormous, beige, the lace is thick and clinging. Nose is malt, floral, light hints of caramel. Front is lightly sweet, the top light, the finish is nicely hopped, dry, highly acidic, and quite Quaffable. I do like a nice ESB, and this one I Likes a lot. Ranks #429 on my top 1000 beer master list.

Muddy brown unfiltered, with great head retention.  Has a cascade nose.  The taste has plenty of hops, but the maltiness comes more to the fore in the taste.  Slightly creamy in texture, and solid bitter aftertaste.  Overall, a great beer.

This quite a bit more bitter than I had anticipated.  Nice grapefruit citrus nose, and a kind of darker amber coloring.  I feel like the hops overshadowed everything else in this beer and totally dominate the finish.  This was good, but more body and a little balance would go a long way to making it awesome.
Excellent beer.  Full flavored, plenty of malt character, and wonderfully bitter on the finish.  Excellent beer.
Great hoopy aroma, with a touch of fruitiness.  Nice balance of hops in the body.  A great ESB.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2004 It could be better.  It failed to impress me when I drank it at first. As I got deeper into the bottle I liked it more. Super malty and good.
The best American ESB Ive had and from Americas best brewpub too!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2003 July 2001: Solid, solid bitter.  Perhaps not as well balanced (not quite as sweet, bit too hoppy) as Vermont Pub, but still a nice example of the style.  Beautiful tawny color and grapefruit nose are highlights.

February 2003:  more pleased with the intense hoppiness this time perhaps; citrusy nature really comes through along with a pleasant pineyness and if you take a large mouthful you get some nice caramel as well.  Great mouthfeel, and though I keep trying to find fault with McNeills instead I find myself rerating them higher.  A true classic.

An all around decent bitter. Im using this comment box to plug their Ruby Ale. Im from Vermont, and believe me, McNeils Ruby Ale is the best beer ever made in the state. One of the best beers Ive EVER had.  A true knockout. Why the brewer decided to make the Ruby Ale a only few months out of the year is baffling.  If you, beer drinker, ever have a chance to get this beer, do it. You will not be disappointed.  It would get a 19 rating.
A good classic bottle conditioned American bitter.
